revision.comment: Lead: Fixup [[Special:Diff/812253013]] by restoring its previous version for stress emphasis of "high controversial" phrase
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Early adulthood}} '''Emerging adulthood''' is a phase of the life span between [[adolescence]] and full-fledged [[adulthood]] which encompasses late adolescence and early adulthood, proposed by [[Jeffrey Arnett]] in a 2000 article in the ''[[American Psychologist]]''.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = Jeffrey Jensen | year = 2000 | title = Emerging adulthood: A theory of development from the late teens through the twenties | url = http://content.apa.org/journals/amp/55/5/469 | journal = [[American Psychologist]] | volume = 55 | issue = 5| pages = 469–480 | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.55.5.469 }}</ref> It primarily describes people living in [[Developed country|developed countries]], but it is also experienced by young people in urban wealthy families in the [[Global south|Global South]].<ref name=Galambos>{{cite journal|last1=Galambos|first1=Nancy|last2=Martinez|first2=M. Loreto|title=Poised for emerging adulthood in Latin America: A pleasure for the privileged|journal=Child Development Perspectives|date=2007|volume=1|issue=2|pages=109–114|doi=10.1111/j.1750-8606.2007.00024.x}}</ref> The term describes young adults who do not have children, do not live in their own home, or do not have sufficient income to become fully independent. Arnett suggests emerging adulthood is the distinct period between 18 and 25 years of age where adolescents become more independent and explore various life possibilities. Arnett argues that this developmental period can be isolated from [[adolescence]] and [[young adulthood]].<ref name=":1" /> Emerging adulthood is a new demographic, is contentiously changing, and some<ref name="Devin Ludwig">{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/devin-ludwig/post_723_b_691244.html| title= Challenges of the Young Adult Generation| last= Ludwig| first= Devin| publisher=''[[Huffington Post]]''| date= August 23, 2010| accessdate =August 24, 2010}}</ref> believe that twenty-somethings have always struggled with "identity exploration, instability, self-focus, and feeling in-between".<ref>{{cite news|last=Marantz Henig|first=Robin|title=What Is It About 20‑Somethings?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/22/magazine/22Adulthood-t.html?pagewanted=all|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 August 2010}}</ref> Arnett called this period "roleless role" because emerging adults do a wide variety of activities, but are not constrained by any sort of "role requirements".<ref name=":1" /> The developmental theory is highly controversial within the developmental field, and developmental psychologists argue over the legitimacy of Arnett's theories and methods.
==Distinction from young adulthood and adolescence==
===Terminology=== Coined by psychology professor Jeffrey Arnett, emerging adulthood has been known variously as "transition age youth",<ref>{{cite|title=Multisystemic Therapy for Emerging Adults With Serious Mental Illness and Justice Involvement|first1=Ashli J.|last1=Sheidow|first2=Michael R.|last2=McCart|journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Practice|volume=23|issue=3|date=August 2016|pages=356–367|doi=10.1016/j.cbpra.2015.09.003}}</ref><ref name=Alexander>{{cite|title=Addressing sexual health behaviour during emerging adulthood: a critical review of the literature|first1=Kamila A|last1=Alexander|first2=Loretta S|last2=Jemmott|first3=Anne M|last3=Teitelman|first4=Patricia|last4=D'Antonio|journal=Journal of Clinical Nursing|volume=24|issue=1-2|date=January 2015|pages=4–18|doi=10.1111/jocn.12640}}</ref><!-- <ref name= Walker/> --> "delayed adulthood",<ref>{{cite|title=Insights on Adolescence from a Life Course Perspective|first1=Monica Kirkpatrick|last1=Johnson|first2=Robert|last2=Crosnoe|first3=Glen H.|last3=Elder Jr.|date=March 2011|journal=Journal of Research on Adolescence|volume=21|issue=1, Special issue|pages=273–280|doi=10.1111/j.1532-7795.2010.00728.x}}</ref> "extended adolescence", "youthhood",<ref>{{cite|title=Religious Zionist Singles and Late-Modern Youth Culture|first=Ari|last=Engelberg|journal=Israel Studies Review|volume=28|issue=2|year=2013|pages=1–17|doi=10.3167/isr.2013.280202}}</ref> "adultolescence",<ref>{{cite|title=Book Reviews|year=2008|journal=Journal of Economic Literature|volume=46|issue=4|pages=989-1041|doi=10.1257/jel.46.4.989}}</ref> and "the [[twixter]] years".<ref name=Smith>{{cite|title=Lost in Transition: The Dark Side of Emerging Adulthood|first1=Christian|last1=Smith|first2=Kari|last2=Christoffersen|first3=Hilary|last3=Davidson|first4=Patricia Snell|last4=Herzog|publisher=Oxford Scholarship Online|date=January 2012|page=15|isbn=9780199828029|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199828029.001.0001}}</ref> Of the various terms, "emerging adulthood" has become popular among sociologists, psychologists, and government agencies as a way to describe this period of life in between adolescence and young adulthood.<ref>{{cite|title=Precedent as a Policy Map: What Miller v. Alabama Tells Us about Emerging Adults and the Direction of Contemporary Youth Services|first=Clark M.|last=Peters|journal=Missouri Law Review|volume=78|issue=4|date=Fall 2013|url=http://scholarship.law.missouri.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4063&context=mlr|quote=In recent decades, sociologists and psychologists have begun to embrace a new developmental stage of 'emerging adulthood,' initially articulated by Professor Jeffrey Arnett." Footnote: "The term is in the process of being embraced by governmental entities as well...employing the term in targeting the needs of young people aged 16–25)."}}</ref><ref>{{cite|title=Between adolescence and adulthood: Rehabilitation research to improve services for youth and young adults|last1=Davis|first1=Maryann|last2=Koroloff|first2=Nancy|last3=Ellison|first3=Marsha Langer|journal=Psychiatric Rehabilitation Journal|volume=35|issue=3|year=2012|pages=167-170|doi=10.2975/35.3.2012.167.170}}</ref><ref name=Walker>{{cite|title=A Theory of Change for Positive Developmental Approaches to Improving Outcomes Among Emerging Adults with Serious Mental Health Conditions|first=Janet S.|last=Walker|journal=The Journal of Behavioral Health Services & Research|date=April 2015|volume=4|issue=2|pages=131–149|doi=10.1007/s11414-015-9455-x}}</ref><!-- <ref name=Smith/><ref name=Alexander/> -->
Compared to other terms that have been used which give the impression that this stage is just a "last hurrah" of adolescence, "emerging adulthood" recognizes the uniqueness of this period of life.<ref name=Smith/> Currently, it is appropriate to define adolescence as the period spanning ages 12 to 18. This is because people in this age group in the United States typically live at home with their parents, are undergoing pubertal changes, attend middle schools and high schools and are involved in a "school-based peer culture". All of these characteristics are no longer normative after the age of 18, and it is, therefore, considered inappropriate to call young adults "adolescence" or "late adolescence". Furthermore, in the United States, the age of 18 is the age at which people are able to legally vote and citizens are granted full rights upon turning 21 years of age.<ref name=arnett />
According to Arnett, the term "young adulthood" suggests that adulthood has already been reached, but most people in the emerging adulthood stage no longer consider themselves adolescents, but do not see themselves entirely as adults either.<ref name=arnett>{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = J. J. | year = 2000 | title = Emerging Adulthood: A theory of development from the late teens through the twenties | journal = [[American Psychologist]] | volume = 55 | issue = 5| page = 477 | doi=10.1037/0003-066x.55.5.469}}</ref> In the past, milestones such as finishing secondary school, finding a job, and getting married clearly marked the entrance to adulthood, but in modern, post-industrialized nations, as positions requiring a college degree have become more common and the average age of marriage has become older the length of time between leaving adolescence and reaching these milestones has been extended, delaying the age at which many young people fully enter adulthood.<ref>{{cite|title=The Transitory Nature of Parent, Sibling and Romantic Partner Relationships in Emerging Adulthood|first1=Avidan|last1=Milevsky|first2=Kristie|last2=Thudium|first3=Jillian|last3=Guldin|publisher=Springer|year=2014|page=1|isbn=9783319066387|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UtIkBAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA1&ots=8iOUHglJSG&dq=%22The%20transition%20from%20adolescence%20to%20adulthood%20is%20a%20significant%20period%20in%20the%20life%20of%20an%20individual.%22&pg=PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> If the years 18–25 are classified as "young adulthood", Arnett believes it is then difficult to find an appropriate term for the thirties. Emerging adults are still in the process of obtaining an education, are unmarried, and are childless. By age thirty, most of these individuals do see themselves as adults, based on the belief that they have more fully formed "individualistic qualities of character" such as self-responsibility, financial independence, and independence in decision-making. Arnett suggests that many of the individualistic characteristics associated with adult status correlate to, but are not dependent upon, the role responsibilities associated with a career, marriage, and/or parenthood.<ref name=":1" />
===Exploration of identity=== One of the most important features of emerging adulthood is that this age period allows for exploration in love, work, and worldviews more than any other age period. The process of identity formation emerges in adolescence but mostly takes place in emerging adulthood. Regarding love, although adolescents in the United States usually begin dating between ages 12 and 14, they usually view this dating as recreational. It is not until emerging adulthood that identity formation in love becomes more serious.<ref name=arnett /> Emerging adults are considering their own developing identities as a reference point for a lifetime relationship partner, so they explore romantically and sexually as there is less parental control.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Emerging adulthood: A theory of development from the late teens through the twenties|last = Arnett|first = Jeffrey|date = 2000|journal = American Psychologist|doi = 10.1037/0003-066x.55.5.469|pmid = |access-date =|volume=55|pages=469–480}}</ref> While in the United States during adolescence dating usually occurs in groups and in situations such as parties and dances, in emerging adulthood, relationships last longer and often include sexual relations as well as cohabitation.<ref>Padgham, J. J., & Blyth, D. A. (1991). "Dating during adolescence". In R. M. Lerner, A. C. Peterson, & J. Brooks-Gunn (Eds.), ''Encyclopedia of adolescence'' (pp. 196-198). New York: Garland.</ref>
As far as work, the majority of working adolescents in the United States tend to see their jobs as a way to make money for recreational activities rather than preparing them for a future career.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bachman | first1 = J. G. | last2 = Schulenberg | first2 = J. | year = 1993 | title = How part-time work intensity relates to drug use, problem behavior, time use, and satisfaction among high school seniors: Are these consequences or just correlates? | url = | journal = Developmental Psychology | volume = 29 | issue = | pages = 220–235 | doi=10.1037/0012-1649.29.2.220}}</ref> In contrast, 18- to 25-year-olds in emerging adulthood view their jobs as a way to obtain the knowledge and skills that will prepare them for their future adulthood careers. Because emerging adults have the possibility of having numerous work experiences, they are able to figure out what type of work they are good at as well find what type of work they want to pursue for the rest of their life.<ref name=":1" /> Undergoing changes in worldviews is a main division of cognitive development during emerging adulthood.<ref name=perry>Perry, W. G. (1999). "Forms of ethical and intellectual development in the college years": "A scheme" San Francisco: Jossey-Bass. (Original work published 1970)</ref>
People in emerging adulthood that choose to attend college often begin college or university with the worldview they were raised with and learned in childhood and adolescence. However, emerging adults who have attended college or university have been exposed to and have considered different worldviews, and eventually commit to a worldview that is distinct from the worldview with which they were raised by the end of their college or university career.<ref name=perry />
===Subjective difference=== When Americans between the ages of 18 and 25 are asked whether they believe they have reached adulthood, most do not answer with a "no" or a "yes", but answer with "In some respects yes, in some respects no".<ref>Arnett, J.J. (in press). Conceptions of the transition to adulthood from adolescence through midlife. ''Journal of Adult Development''</ref> It is clear from this ambiguity that most emerging adults in the United States feel they have completed adolescence but not yet entered adulthood.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = J.J. | year = 1994a | title = Are college students adults? Their conceptions of the transition to adulthood | url = | journal = Journal of Adult Development | volume = 1 | issue = | pages = 154–168 | doi=10.1007/bf02277582}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = J.J. | year = 1997 | title = Young People's Conceptions of the Transition to Adulthood | url = http://yas.sagepub.com/content/29/1/3.short | journal = Youth & Society | volume = 29 | issue = | pages = 1–23 | doi=10.1177/0044118x97029001001}}</ref><ref name=alone>{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = J. J. | year = 1998 | title = Learning to Stand Alone: The Contemporary American Transition to Adulthood in Cultural and Historical Context | url = http://content.karger.com/ProdukteDB/produkte.asp?Doi=22591 | journal = Human Development | volume = 41 | issue = | pages = 295–315 | doi=10.1159/000022591}}</ref>
A number of studies have shown that regarding people in their late teens and early twenties in the United States, demographic qualities such as completing their education, finding a career, getting married, and becoming parents are not the criteria used in determining whether they have reached adulthood.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = J.J. | year = 1997 | title = Young people's conceptions of the transition to adulthood | url = | journal = Youth & Society | volume = 29 | issue = | pages = 1–23 | doi=10.1177/0044118x97029001001}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">Arnett, J.J. (in press). Conceptions of the transition to adulthood from adolescence through midlife. ''Journal of Adult Development.''</ref><ref name="Greene, A. L. 1992">{{cite journal | last1 = Greene | first1 = A. L. | last2 = Wheatley | first2 = S.M. | last3 = Aldava | first3 = J. F. | last4 = IV | first4 = | year = 1992 | title = Stages on life's way: Adolescents' implicit theories of the life course | url = | journal = Journal of Adolescent Research | volume = 7 | issue = | pages = 364–381 | doi=10.1177/074355489273006}}</ref><ref name="Scheer, S.D. 1994">Scheer, S.D., Unger, D.G., & Brown, M. (1994, February). Adolescents becoming adults: Attributes for adulthood. Poster presented at the biennial meeting of the Society for Research on Adolescence, San Diego, CA</ref> Rather, the criteria that determine whether adulthood has been reached are character qualities, such as being able to make independent decisions and taking responsibility for one's self.<ref name=alone /><ref name="Greene, A. L. 1992"/><ref name="Scheer, S.D. 1994"/> In America, these character qualities are usually experienced in the mid to late twenties, thus confirming that emerging adulthood is distinct subjectively.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===Why emerging adulthood is distinct demographically=== Emerging adulthood is the sole age period where there is nothing that is demographically consistent.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rindfuss | first1 = R. R. | year = 1991 | title = The Young adult years: Diversity, structural change, and fertility | url = | journal = Demography | volume = 28 | issue = | pages = 493–512 | doi=10.2307/2061419}}</ref><ref>Wallace, C. (1995, April). "How old is young and young is old? The restructuring of age and the life course in Europe". Paper presented at Youth 2000: An International Conference, Middlesbrough, UK</ref> At this time, adolescents in the United States up to age 20, over 95% live at home with at least one parent, 98% are not married, under 10% have become parents, and more than 95% attend school.<ref name=census>[[United States Census Bureau]]. (1997). "Statistical abstracts of the United States": 1997. Washington, DC: Author</ref> Similarly, people in their thirties are also demographically normative: 75% are married, 75% are parents, and under 10% attend school.<ref name=census /> Residential status and school attendance are two reasons that the period of emerging adulthood is incredibly distinct demographically. Regarding residential status, emerging adults in the United States have very diverse living situations.<ref name=arnett /> About one third of emerging adults attend college and spend a few years living independently while partially relying on adults.<ref name="Goldscheider, F. 1994">{{cite journal | last1 = Goldscheider | first1 = F. | last2 = Goldscheider | first2 = C. | year = 1994 | title = Leaving and returning home in 20th century America | url = | journal = Population Bulletin | volume = 48 | issue = 4| pages = 1–35 }}</ref>
Contrastingly, 40% of emerging adults do not attend college but live independently and work full-time.<ref name="Goldscheider, F. 1994"/> Finally, around two-thirds of emerging adults in the United States cohabitate with a romantic partner.<ref>Michael, R. T., Gagnon, J. H., Laumann, E. O., & Kolata, G. (1995). "Sex in America: A definitive survey". New York: Warner Books</ref> Regarding school attendance, emerging adults are extremely diverse in their educational paths (Arnett, 2000, p. 470-471). Over 60% of emerging adults in the United States enter college or university the year after they graduate from high school.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = S. M. | last2 = Spain | first2 = D. | year = 1996 | title = Women, work, and family in America | url = | journal = Population Bulletin | volume = 51 | issue = 3| pages = 1–48 }}</ref> However, the years that follow college are extremely diverse – only about 32% of 25- to 29-year-olds have finished four or more years of college.<ref name=census />
This is because higher education is usually pursued non-continuously, where some pursue education while they also work, and some do not attend school for periods of time.<ref name=arnett /> Further contributing to the variance, about one third of emerging adults with bachelor's degrees pursue a postgraduate education within a year of earning their bachelor's degree.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Mogelonsky | first1 = M. | year = 1996 | title = The rocky road to adulthood | url = | journal = American Demographics | volume = 18 | issue = 26–36| page = 56 }}</ref> Thus, because there is so much demographic instability, especially in residential status and school attendance, it is clear that emerging adulthood is a distinct entity based on its demographically non-normative qualities, at least in the United States. Some emerging adults end up moving back home after college graduation, which tests the demographic of dependency. During college, they may be completely independent, but that could quickly change afterwards when they are trying to find a full-time job with little direction on where to start their career.
==Physiological development==
===Biological changes=== Emerging adulthood and adolescence differ significantly with regard to puberty and hormonal development.<ref name="Eisenberg"/> While there is considerable overlap between the onset of puberty and the developmental stage referred to as adolescence, there are considerably fewer hormonal and physical changes taking place in individuals between the ages of 18–25. Emerging adults have reached a stage of full hormonal maturity and are fully, physically equipped for sexual reproduction.
Emerging adulthood is usually thought of as a time of peak physical health and performance as individuals are usually less susceptible to disease and more physically agile during this period than later stages of adulthood. However, emerging adults are generally more likely to contract [[Sexually transmitted disease|sexually transmitted infections]], as well as to adopt unhealthy behavioral patterns and lifestyle choices.<ref>Arnett, J. (2012). Adolescence and emerging adulthood: A cultural approach. (5th ed.). Pearson Education Retrieved from http://www.pearsonhighered.com/assets/hip/us/hip_us_pearsonhighered/samplechapter/0205892493.pdf{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Cognitive development=== While many people believe that the brains of emerging adults are fully developed, they are in fact still developing into their adult forms. Many connections within the brain are strengthened and those that are unused are pruned away.<ref name="Beck">Beck, M. (2012). "Delayed Development: 20-Somethings Blame the Brain." Retrieved from https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390443713704577601532208760746.</ref> Several brain structures develop that allow for greater processing of emotions and social information. Areas of the brain used for planning and for processing risk and rewards also undergo important developments during this stage.<ref name="Beck"/> These developments in brain structure and the resulting implications are one factor that leads emerging adults to be considered more mature than adolescents. This is due to the fact that they make fewer impulsive decisions and rely more on planning and evaluating of situations.
While brain structures continue to develop during emerging adulthood, the cognition of emerging adults is an area that receives the majority of attention. Arnett explains, "Emerging adulthood is a critical stage for the emergence of complex forms of thinking required in complex societies."<ref name="Arnett, J. 2006">Arnett, J. (2006). "Emerging Adults in America, Coming of Age in the 21st Century." [[American Psychological Association]].</ref> Crucial changes take place in their sense of self and capacity for self-reflection. At this stage, emerging adults often decide on a particular worldview and are able to recognize that other perspectives exist and are valid as well.<ref name="Arnett, J. 2006"/> While cognition generally becomes more complex, education level plays an important role in this development.<ref name="Arnett, J. 2006"/> Not all emerging adults reach the same advanced level in cognition because of the variety of education received during this age period.
===Abnormal development=== Much research has been directed at studying the onset of lifetime [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM]] disorders to dispel the common thought that most disorders begin earlier in life. Because of this reasoning, many people that show signs of disorders do not seek help due to its stigmatization. The research shows that those with various disorders will not feel symptoms until emerging adulthood. Kessler and Merikangas reported that "50% of emerging adults between the ages of 18 and 25 experience at least one psychiatric disorder." Not only is the emergence of various disorders prevalent in emerging adulthood, but the chance of developing a disorder drastically decreases at age 28.<ref name="Kessler 2007">{{cite journal | last1 = Kessler | first1 = Ronald C. | last2 = Amminger | first2 = G. P. | last3 = Aguilar‐Gaxiola | first3 = Sergio | last4 = Alonso | first4 = Jodi | last5 = Lee | first5 = Sing | last6 = Ustun | first6 = T. B. | year = 2007 | title = Age of onset of mental disorders: A review of recent literature | journal = Curr Opin Psychiatry | volume = 20 | issue = 4| pages = 359–64| pmc=1925038 | pmid=17551351 | doi=10.1097/YCO.0b013e32816ebc8c}}</ref><ref>Tanner, J. L. (March, 2010). "Mental health in emerging adulthood. The changing spirituality of emerging adults project." Washington, DC: [[The Catholic University of America]], The Institute for Policy Research and Catholic Studies. Retrieved From http://changingsea.org/papersyn.htm</ref>
Seventy-five percent of any lifetime DSM-IV anxiety, mood, impulse-control and substance abuse disorder begins before age 24. Most onsets at this age will not be, or become, [[Comorbidity|comorbid]]. The median onset interquartile range of [[substance use disorder]]s is 18–27, while the median onset age is 20. The median onset age of mood disorders is 25.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kessler | first1 = RC | last2 = Berglund | first2 = P | last3 = Demler | first3 = O | last4 = Jin | first4 = R | last5 = Merikangas | first5 = KR | last6 = Walters | first6 = EE | year = 2005 | title = Lifetime Prevalence and Age-of-Onset Distributions of DSM-IV Disorders in the National Comorbidity Survey Replication | url = | journal = Arch Gen Psychiatry | volume = 62 | issue = 6| pages = 593–602 | doi = 10.1001/archpsyc.62.6.593 | pmid=15939837}}</ref>
Even disorders that begin earlier, like [[Spectrum approach#Broad spectrum approach|schizophrenia spectrum diagnoses]], can reveal themselves within the age range of emerging adulthood. Often, patients will not seek help until several years of symptoms have passed, if at all.<ref name="Kessler 2007" /> For example, those diagnosed with [[social anxiety disorder]] will rarely seek treatment until age 27 or later. Typically, symptoms of more severe disorders, such as [[major depression]], begin at age 25 as well.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Regier | first1 = Darrel A. | last2 = Rae | first2 = Donald S. | last3 = Narrow | first3 = William E. | last4 = Kaelber | first4 = Charles T. | last5 = Schatzberg | first5 = Alan F. | year = 1998 | title = Prevalence of anxiety disorders and their comorbidity with mood and addictive disorders | url = http://psycnet.apa.org/psycinfo/1998-10311-004 | journal = The British Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 173 | issue = 34| pages = 24–8| pmid = 9829013 }}</ref><ref>Beck, Melinda. (2012, August 20). Delayed Development: 20-Somethings Blame the Brain. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]].'' Retrieved From https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390443713704577601532208760746.</ref>
With the exception of some [[phobia]]s, symptoms of many disorders begin to appear and are diagnosable during emerging adulthood. Major efforts have been taken to educate the public and influence those with symptoms to seek treatment past adolescence. There is minimal but intriguing evidence that those who attend college appear to have less of a chance of showing symptoms of DSM-IV disorders. In one study, "they were significantly less likely to have a diagnosis of drug use disorder or nicotine dependence". In addition, "bipolar disorder was less common in individuals attending college". However, other research reports that chance of alcohol abuse and addiction is increased with college student status.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Blanco | first1 = Carlos | last2 = Okuda | first2 = Mayumi | last3 = Wright | first3 = Crystal | last4 = Hasin | first4 = Deborah | last5 = Grant | first5 = Bridget | last6 = Liu | first6 = Shang-Min | last7 = Olfson | first7 = Mark | year = 2008 | title = Mental Health of College Students and Their Non–College-Attending Peers Results From the National Epidemiologic Study on Alcohol and Related Conditions | url = http://psycnet.apa.org/psycinfo/1998-10311-004 | journal = Arch Gen Psychiatry | volume = 65 | issue = 12| pages = 1429| doi=10.1001/archpsyc.65.12.1429| pmc = 2734947 }}</ref>
==Relationships==
===Parent-child relationship=== Emerging adulthood is characterized by a reevaluation of the [[Parent|parent-child relationship]], primarily in regard to autonomy. As a child switches from the role of a dependent to the role of a fellow adult, the family dynamic changes significantly. At this stage, it is important that parents acknowledge and accept their child's status as an adult.<ref>Blos, P. (1985). "Son and father: Before and beyond the Oedipus complex." ''New York: Free Press''.</ref> This process may include gestures such as allowing increased amounts of privacy and extending trust. Granting this recognition assists the increasingly independent offspring in forming a strong sense of identity and exploration at a time when it is most crucial.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bartle-Haring | first1 = S. | last2 = Brucker | first2 = P. | last3 = Hock | first3 = E. | year = 2002 | title = The impact of parental separation anxiety on identity development in late adolescence and early adulthood | url = | journal = Journal of Adolescent Research | volume = 17 | issue = | pages = 439–450 | doi=10.1177/0743558402175001}}</ref>
There is varied evidence regarding the continuity of emerging adults' relationships with parents, although most of the research supports the fact that there is moderate stability. A parent-child relationship of higher quality often results in greater affection and contact in emerging adulthood.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Belsky | first1 = J. | last2 = Jaffee | first2 = S. | last3 = Hsieh | first3 = K. | last4 = Silva | first4 = P. | year = 2001 | title = Child-rearing antecedents of intergenerational relations in young adulthood: A prospective study | url = | journal = Developmental Psychology | volume = 37 | issue = | pages = 801–813 | doi=10.1037/0012-1649.37.6.801}}</ref> [[Attachment theory|Attachment styles]] tend to remain stable from infancy to adulthood.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Waters | first1 = E. | last2 = Weinfield | first2 = N. S. | last3 = Hamilton | first3 = C. E. | year = 2000 | title = The stability of attachment security from infancy to adolescence and early adulthood | url = | journal = Child Development | volume = 71 | issue = | pages = 703–706 | doi=10.1111/1467-8624.00179}}</ref> An initial secure attachment assists in healthy separation from parents while still retaining intimacy, resulting in adaptive psychological function.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Leondari | first1 = A. | last2 = Kiosseoglou | first2 = G. | year = 2000 | title = The relationship of parental attachment and psychological separation to the psychological functioning of young adults | url = | journal = Journal of Social Psychology | volume = 140 | issue = | pages = 451–464 | doi=10.1080/00224540009600484}}</ref> Changes in attachment are often associated with negative life events, as described below.
[[Divorce]] and remarriage of parents often result in a weaker parent-child relationship,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Aquilino | first1 = W | year = 1994a | title = Impact of childhood family structure on young adults' relationships with parents | url = | journal = Journal of Marriage and the Family | volume = 56 | issue = | pages = 295–313 | doi=10.2307/353101}}</ref> even if no adverse effects were apparent during childhood.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cherlin | first1 = A. J. | last2 = Chase-Lansdale | first2 = P. L. | last3 = McRae | first3 = C. | year = 1998 | title = Effects of parental divorce on mental health throughout the life course | url = | journal = American Sociological Review | volume = 63 | issue = | pages = 239–249 | doi=10.2307/2657325}}</ref> When parental divorce occurs in early adulthood, it has a strong, negative impact on the child's relationship with their father.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Aquilino | first1 = W | year = 1994b | title = Later-life parental divorce and widow-hood: Impact on young adults' assessment of parent-child relations | url = | journal = Journal of Marriage and the Family | volume = 56 | issue = | pages = 908–922 | doi=10.2307/353602}}</ref>
However, if parents and children maintain a good relationship throughout the divorce process, it could act as a buffer and reduce the negative effects of the experience. A positive parent-child relationship after parental divorce may also be facilitated by the child's understanding of divorce. Understanding the complexity of the situation and not dwelling on the negative aspects may actually assist a young adult's adjustment, as well as their success in their own romantic relationships.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Shulman | first1 = S. | last2 = Scharf | first2 = M. | last3 = Lumer | first3 = D. | last4 = Maurer | first4 = O. | year = 2001 | title = How young adults perceive parental divorce: The role of their relationships with their fathers and mothers | url = | journal = Journal of Divorce and Remarriage | volume = 34 | issue = | pages = 3–17 | doi=10.1300/j087v34n03_02}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Mahl | first1 = D | year = 2001 | title = The influence of parental divorce on the romantic relationship beliefs of young adults | url = | journal = Journal of Divorce and Remarriage | volume = 34 | issue = | pages = 89–118 | doi=10.1300/j087v34n03_06}}</ref>
Despite the increasing need for autonomy that emerging adults experience, there is also a continuing need for support from parents, although this need is often different and less dependent than that of children and earlier adolescents. Many people over the age of 18 still require financial support in order to further their education and career,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Semyonov | first1 = M. | last2 = Lewin-Epstein | first2 = N. | year = 2001 | title = The impact of parental transfers on living standards of married children | url = | journal = Social Indicators Research | volume = 54 | issue = | pages = 115–137 | doi=10.1023/a:1011081529592}}</ref> despite an otherwise independent lifestyle. Furthermore, emotional support remains important during this transition period. Parental engagement with low marital conflict results in better adjustment for college students.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Nicholson | first1 = J. | last2 = Phillips | first2 = M. | last3 = Peterson | first3 = C. | last4 = Battistutta | first4 = D. | year = 2002 | title = Relationship between the parenting styles of biological parents and stepparents and the adjustment of young adult stepchildren | url = | journal = Journal of Divorce and Remarriage | volume = 36 | issue = | pages = 57–76 | doi=10.1300/j087v36n03_04}}</ref> This balance of autonomy and dependency may seem contradictory, but relinquishing control while providing necessary support may strengthen the bond between parents and offspring and may even provide space for children to be viewed as sources of support.<ref>Aquilino, W. (2006). "Family Relationships and Support Systems in Emerging Adulthood." In J. J. Arnett (Ed.) ''Emerging adults in America: Coming of age in the 21st century.'' (pp. 193-217). Washington, DC, US: [[American Psychological Association]].</ref>
Parental support may come in the form of co-residence, which has varied effects on an emerging adult's adjustment. The proportion of young adults living with their parents has steadily increased in recent years, largely due to financial strain, difficulty finding employment, and the necessity of higher education in the job field.<ref>{{cite news |title=Census Bureau agrees with parents: Yes, young adults still home |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/11/census-bureau-more-young-adults-live-with-parents.html |work=Los Angeles Times |date=November 3, 2011}}</ref> The economic benefit of a period of co-residence may assist an emerging adult in exploration of career options. In households with lower socioeconomic status, this arrangement may have the added benefit of the young adult providing support for the family, both financial and otherwise.
Co-residence can also have negative effects on an emerging adult's adjustment and autonomy. This may hinder parents' ability to acknowledge their child as an adult,<ref>White, N. R. (2002). "Not under my roof! Young people's experience of home." ''Youth & Society,34'', 214–231.</ref> while home-leaving promotes psychological growth and satisfying adult-to-adult relationships with parents characterized by less confrontation.<ref>Arnett, J. J. (2004). "Emerging adulthood: The winding road from the late teens through the twenties." ''New York: Oxford University Press.''</ref> Living in physically separate households can help both a young adult and a parent acknowledge the changing nature of their relationship.<ref>Dubas, J. S., & Petersen, A. C. (1996). "Geographical distance from parents and adjustment during adolescence and young adulthood." In J. Graber & J. Dubas (Eds.), "New directions for child development: Vol. 71. Leaving home: Understanding the transition to adulthood" (pp. 3—20). ''San Francisco: Jossey-Bass''.</ref>
===Sexual relationships=== There are a wide variety of factors that influence [[sexual relationship]]s during emerging adulthood; this includes beliefs about certain sexual behaviors and marriage. For example, among emerging adults in the United States, it is common for [[oral sex]] to not be considered "real sex".<ref name = "Eisenberg">Eisenberg, M. E. (2010). Sex in Emerging Adulthood: A Decade in the Sexual Gap.''Changing Sea''. Retrieved September 20, 2012</ref> In the 1950s and 1960s, about 75% of people between the ages of 20–24 engaged in [[premarital sex]]. Today, that number is 90%.<ref name = "Eisenberg" /> [[Unintended pregnancy]] and [[sexually transmitted disease|sexually transmitted infections and diseases]] (STIs/STDs) are a central issue. As individuals move through emerging adulthood, they are more likely to engage in monogamous sexual relationships and practice [[safe sex]].<ref name = "Eisenberg" />
Across most OECD countries, marriage rates are falling, the [[age at first marriage]] is rising,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/els/family/SF_3_1_Marriage_and_divorce_rates.pdf|publisher=OECD|work=OECD Family Database|title=Marriage and divorce rates}}</ref> and [[cohabitation]] among unmarried couples is increasing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/els/soc/SF3_3_Cohabitation_rate_and_prevalence_of_other_forms_of_partnership_Jan2013.pdf|title=Cohabitation rate and prevalence of other forms of partnership|publisher=OECD|work=OECD Family Database}}</ref> The [[Western European marriage pattern]] has traditionally been characterised by marriage in the mid twenties, especially for women, with a generally small age difference between the spouses, a significant proportion of women who remain unmarried, and the establishment of a [[Neolocal residence|neolocal household]] after the couple has married.<ref>Stone, Linda. (2010). ''Kinship and Gender''. Boulder, Colorado: Westview Press, pp. 231–36, {{ISBN|0813344026}}.</ref><ref>Schofield, Phillipp R. (2003). ''Peasant and community in Medieval England, 1200–1500''. Medieval culture and society. New York: Palgrave-Macmillan. p 98, {{ISBN|0333647106}}.</ref><ref name="autogenerated82">Laslett, Peter. (1965). The World We Have Lost. New York, New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. p. 82, {{ISBN|0415315271}}.</ref>
[[Housing affordability]] has been linked to [[Owner-occupancy|home ownership]] rates, and [[Demography|demographic research]]ers have argued for a link between the rising age at first marriage and the rising age of first home ownership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rba.gov.au/publications/submissions/housing-and-housing-finance/inquiry-into-home-ownership/home-ownership-rates.html|title=Home Ownership Rates - Submission to the Inquiry into Home Ownership June 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>https://www.newyorkfed.org/medialibrary/media/research/economists/tracy/7519_Transition_to_Homeownership.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mainstreet.com/article/why-first-time-homebuyers-are-waiting-to-buy-houses-until-after-marriage |title=Why First-Time Homebuyers Are Waiting to Buy a House Until After Marriage - MainStreet |date=13 April 2016 |publisher= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160413021546/https://www.mainstreet.com/article/why-first-time-homebuyers-are-waiting-to-buy-houses-until-after-marriage |archivedate=2016-04-13 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2011/10/11/average-age-of-first-time-homeowners-remains-high/ |title=Average age of first-time homeowners remains high – The Daily Universe |date=10 July 2016 |publisher= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160710202225/http://universe.byu.edu/2011/10/11/average-age-of-first-time-homeowners-remains-high/ |archivedate=2016-07-10 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/11/11/record-share-of-young-women-are-living-with-their-parents-relatives/|title=Record share of young women are living with their parents, relatives|date=11 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
==Culture== Demographers distinguish between developing countries, which constitute more than 80% of the world's population,<ref>United Nations Development Programme (2006). Human Development Report, 2006. New York: Author.</ref> and the economically advanced, industrialized nations that form the Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development (OECD). This includes countries like the United States, Canada, Western Europe, Japan, South Korea, and Australia, all of which have significantly higher median incomes and educational attainment and significantly lower rates of illness, disease, and early death.<ref name="Cultural Psychology">Arnett, J.J. (2011). "Emerging adulthood(s): The Cultural Psychology of a New Life Stage." In ''L.A. Jensen (Ed.)'', "Bridging cultural and developmental approaches to psychology: New Synthesis in theory, research, and policy," (pp. 255–275). New York: [[Oxford University Press]].</ref>
The theory of emerging adulthood is specifically applicable to cultures within these OECD nations,<ref name="Cultural Psychology"/> and as a stage of development has only emerged over the past half century.<ref name=" What Is It?">{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = J. J. | year = 2007 | title = Emerging Adulthood: What Is It, and What Is It Good For? | url = | journal = Child Development Perspectives | volume = 1 | issue = | pages = 68–73 | doi = 10.1111/j.1750-8606.2007.00016.x }}</ref> It is specific to "certain cultural-demographic conditions, specifically widespread education and training beyond secondary school and entry into marriage and parenthood in the late twenties (or early thirties) or beyond".<ref>Arnett, J.J. (2011). Emerging adulthood(s): The Cultural Psychology of a New Life Stage. In L.A. Jensen (Ed.), Bridging cultural and developmental approaches to psychology: New Synthesis in theory, research, and policy (pp. 255–275). New York: Oxford University Press.</ref>
Furthermore, emerging adulthood occurs only within societies that allow for occupational shifts, with emerging adults often experiencing frequent job changes before settling on particular job by the age of 30.<ref name=" What Is It?"/> Arnett also argues that emerging adulthood happens in cultures that allow for a period of time between adolescence and marriage, the marker of adulthood.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Arnett|first1=Jeffrey|title=Emerging Adulthood: A Theory of Development From the Late Teens Through the Twenties|journal=American Psychologist|date=2000|pages=469–480|doi=10.1037/0003-066x.55.5.469|volume=55}}</ref> Such marital and occupational instability found among emerging adults can be attributed to the strong sense of individualization found in cultures that allow for this stage of development; in individualized cultures, traditional familial and institutional constraints have become less pronounced than in previous times or in unindustrialized/developing cultures, allowing for more personal freedom in life decisions.<ref name=" What Is It?"/> However, emerging adulthood even occurs in industrialized nations that do not value individualization, as is the case in some Asian countries discussed below.
Up until the latter portion of the 20th century in OECD countries, and contemporarily in developing countries around the world, young people made the transition from adolescence to young adulthood around or by the age of 22, when they settled into long-lasting, obligation-filled familial and occupational roles.<ref name="Cultural Psychology"/> Therefore, in societies where this trend still prevails, emerging adulthood does not exist as a widespread stage of development.
Among OECD countries, there is a general "one size fits all" model in regards to emerging adulthood, having all undergone the same demographic changes that resulted in this new stage of development between adolescence and young adulthood. However, the shape emerging adulthood takes can even vary between different OECD countries,<ref name="Cultural Psychology"/> and researchers have only recently begun exploring such cross-national differences.<ref name=" What Is It?"/> For instance, researchers have determined that Europe is the area where emerging adulthood lasts the longest, with high levels of government assistance and median marriage ages nearing 30,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Douglas | first1 = C.B. | year = 2007 | title = From duty to desire: Emerging adulthood in Europe and its consequences | url = | journal = Child Development Perspectives | volume = 1 | issue = | pages = 101–108 | doi=10.1111/j.1750-8606.2007.00023.x}}</ref> compared to the U.S. where the median marriage age is 27.<ref>[[United States Census Bureau]] (2009). Statistical abstract of the United States. Washington, DC: U.S. Government Printing Office.</ref>
Emerging adult communities in East Asia may be most dissimilar from their European and American counterparts, for while they share the benefits of affluent societies with strong education and welfare systems, they do not share as strong a sense of individualization. Historically and currently, East Asian cultures have emphasized collectivism more so than those in the West.<ref name="Cultural Psychology"/> For instance, while Asian emerging adults similarly engage in individualistic identity exploration and personal development, they do so within more constrictive boundaries set by familial obligation. For example, European and American emerging adults consistently list financial independence as a key marker of adulthood, while Asian emerging adults consistently list capable of supporting parents financially as a marker with equal weight.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Nelson | first1 = L.J. | last2 = Badger | first2 = S. | last3 = Wu | first3 = B. | year = 2004 | title = The influence of culture in emerging adulthood: Perspectives of Chinese college students | url = | journal = International Journal of Behavioral Development | volume = 28 | issue = | pages = 26–36 | doi=10.1080/01650250344000244}}</ref> Furthermore, while casual dating and premarital sex has become normative in the West, in Asia parents still discourage such practices, where they remain "rare and forbidden".<ref name="Cultural Psychology"/> In fact, about 75% of emerging adults in the U.S. and Europe report having had premarital sexual relations by the age of 20, whereas less than 20% in Japan and South Korea reported the same.<ref>Hatfield, E., & Rapson, R. L. (2006). Love and sex: Cross-cultural perspectives. New York: University Press of America.</ref>
While emerging adulthood exemplars are found mainly within the middle and upper classes of OECD countries, the stage of development still seems to occur across classes, with the main difference between different ones being length—on average, young people in lower social classes tend to enter adulthood two years before those in upper classes.<ref name="Cultural Psychology"/>
While emerging adulthood occurs on a wide scale only in OECD countries, developing countries may also exhibit similar phenomena in certain population subgroups. In contrast to those in poor or rural parts of developing nations, who have no emerging adulthood and sometimes no adolescence due to comparatively early entry into marriage and adult-like work, young people in wealthier urban classes have begun to enter stages of development that resemble emerging adulthood, and the amount to do so is rising.<ref name="Cultural Psychology"/> Such individuals may develop a bicultural or hybrid identity, with part of themselves identifying with local culture and another part participating in the professional culture of the global economy. One finds examples of such a situation among the middle class young people in India, who lead the globalized economic sector while still, for the most part, preferring to have arranged marriages and taking care of their parents in old age.<ref>Chaudhary, N., & Sharma, N. (2007). India. In J.J. Arnett (Ed.) International encyclopedia of adolescence (pp. 4420459). New York: Routledge.</ref> While it is more common for emerging adulthood to occur in OECD countries, it is not always true that all young people of those societies have the opportunity to experience these years of change and exploration.<ref name=":1" />
==Media== Emerging adulthood is not just an idea being talked about by psychologists, the media has propagated the concept as well. [[Hollywood]] has produced multiple movies where the main conflict seems to be a "grown" adult's reluctance to actually "grow" up and take on responsibility. ''[[Failure to Launch]]'' and ''[[Step Brothers (film)|Step Brothers]]'' are extreme examples of this concept. While most takes on emerging adulthood (and the problems that it can cause) are shown in a light-humored attempt to poke fun at the idea, a few films have taken a more serious approach to the plight. ''[[Adventureland (film)|Adventureland]]'', ''[[Take Me Home Tonight (film)|Take Me Home Tonight]]'', ''[[Cyrus (2010 comedy-drama film)|Cyrus]]'' and ''[[Jeff, Who Lives at Home]]'' are comedy-dramas that exhibit the plight of today's emerging adult. Television also is capitalizing on the concept of emerging adulthood with sitcoms such as ''[[$h*! My Dad Says]]'' and ''[[Big Lake (TV series)|Big Lake]]''.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/22/magazine/22Adulthood-t.html?_r=4&adxnnl=1&pagewanted=1&adxnnlx=1348760895-hf3X3qwNQJMSlhtRsTjX6Q | work=The New York Times | title=What Is It About 20-Somethings? | date=August 18, 2010}}</ref>
However, it is not just on television where society sees the world becoming aware of this trend. In spring 2010, ''[[The New Yorker]]'' magazine showcased a picture of a post-grad hanging his [[PhD]] on the wall of his bedroom as his parents stood in the doorway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thegloss.com/career/whats-the-matter-with-kids-today/|title=What's The Matter With Kids Today?|date=19 August 2010|publisher=}}</ref> People do not have to seek out these media sources to find documentation of the emerging adulthood phenomenon. News sources about the topic are abundant. Nationwide, it is being found that people entering their 20s are faced with multitudes of living problems creating problems that this age group has received a lot of attention for. The [[Occupy movement]] is an example of what has happened to the youth of today and exhibits the frustration of today's emerging adults. Other television shows and films showcasing emerging/early adulthood are ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'', and ''[[Less Than Zero (film)|Less Than Zero]].''
== Criticism ==
The concept of emerging adulthood has not been without its criticisms. Sociologists have pinpointed that it neglects class differences.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bynner|first=J.|date=2005|title=Rethinking the youth phase of the life course: The case for emerging adulthood?|url=|journal=Journal of Youth Studies|volume=8|pages=367–384|via=|doi=10.1080/13676260500431628}}</ref> While it might be true that middle class children in Western societies are spoiled for choice and can afford to postpone life decisions, there are other young people who have no choices at all, and stay in the parental home not because they want to, but because they cannot afford a life of their own: They experience a period of "arrested adulthood".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Arrested adulthood: The changing nature of identity-maturity in the late-modern world.|last=Côté|first=James|publisher=New York University Press|year=2000|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref>
A more theoretical criticism comes from developmental psychologists, who regard all stage theories as outdated. They argue that development is a dynamic interactive process, which is different for every individual, because every individual has their own experiences. Inventing a stage that only describes (not explains) a time period in the life of a few individuals (mostly white middle class young people living in Western societies within this decade), and has nothing to say about people living in different conditions or different points in history is not a scientific approach.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hendry|first=L. B.|last2=Kloep|first2=M.|date=2007|title=Examining emerging adulthood: Investigating the emperor's new clothes?|url=|journal=Child Development Perspectives|volume=1 | issue = 2 |pages=74–79|via=|doi=10.1111/j.1750-8606.2007.00017.x}}</ref>
Arnett has taken up some of these critical points in public discussion.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Arnett|first=J. J.|date=2006|title=Emerging adulthood in Europe: A response to Bynner|url=|journal=Journal of Youth Studies|volume=9|pages=111–123|via=|doi=10.1080/13676260500523671}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Debating Emerging Adulthood: Stage or Process?|last=Arnett|first=J. J.|last2=Kloep|first2=M.|last3=Hendry|first3=L. B.|last4=Tanner|first4=J.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2011|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |last = Jensen Arnett |first = Jeffrey |title = Emerging Adulthood: The Winding Road From the Late Teens Through the Twenties |publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] |year = 2004 |pages= 280 |isbn = 0-19-517314-7 }} *{{cite book |title=20 Something Manifesto: Quarter-Lifers Speak Out About Who They Are, What They Want, and How to Get It |last=Hassler |first=Christine |authorlink= |year=2008 |publisher=New World Library |location= |isbn=1-57731-595-2 |page= |pages=352 |url=http://www.christinehassler.com/generation-x/twenty-something-books/ }} *{{cite journal | last1 = Etengoff | first1 = C | year = 2011 | title = An Exploration of religious gender differences amongst Jewish-American emerging adults of different socio-religious subgroups | url = | journal = Archive for the Psychology of Religion | volume = 33 | issue = | pages = 371–391 | doi=10.1163/157361211x607316}} *{{cite journal | last1 = Etengoff | first1 = C. | last2 = Daiute | first2 = C. | year = 2013 | title = Sunni-Muslim American Religious Development during Emerging Adulthood | url = | journal = Journal of Adolescent Research | volume = 28 | issue = 6| pages = 690–714 | doi=10.1177/0743558413477197}}
==External links== *[http://www.ssea.org/ Society for the Study of Emerging Adulthood] *[[University of Pennsylvania]] [http://www.transad.pop.upenn.edu/blog Transition to Adulthood Blog] *{{cite web | url= http://blogs.pitch.com/wayward/2010/08/better_living_in_emerging_adul.php | title= How to Survive Emerging Adulthood: A Playlist | last= Hrabe | first= Ian | publisher= The Pitch | date= Aug 24, 2010 | accessdate = Aug 24, 2010 }}

revision.text:
'''Environmental restoration''' is a term common in the citizens’ [[environmental movement]]. '''Environmental restoration''' is closely allied with (or perhaps sometimes used interchangeably with) ''[[ecological restoration]]'' or ''[[environmental remediation]]''. In the U.S., remediation is the term used more in the realms of industry, public policy, and the civil services.
In the 1987 edition of his book ''Restoring the Earth: How Americans are Working to Renew our Damaged Environment'', scientific editor and writer [[John Berger (author)|John J. Berger]] defined environmental restoration (or “natural resource restoration”) as follows: ''"… A process in which a damaged resource is renewed. Biologically. Structurally. Functionally."''
==Natural environment== The ongoing growth of human population in the world and its associated impacts,{{why|date=March 2012}} mean that the need for ecological restoration has become increasingly clear.{{citation needed|date=March 2012}} The old adage "an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure" points to the fact that ecological restoration is not always successful (or only over long spans of time) and, when feasible, is often difficult and expensive. Environmental restoration is often neglected, either being overlooked or being deemed inexpedient or of a low priority. However, in much of the industrialized world, it has been increasingly demanded by the public, at least since the early 1970s if not before.{{citation needed|date=March 2012}}
The interest and activity in environmental restoration has given rise to a new branch of research and applied techniques within biology, [[restoration ecology]].
Environmental restoration has been applied in aquatic situations ([[lake]]s, [[stream]]s, [[river]]s, [[wetland]]s, etc.) and terrestrial ones (grasslands, [[forest]]s, [[desert]]s, flatlands, hill country, mountain slopes, etc.).
==Approaches== Environmental restoration involves many different approaches and technologies depending on the requirements of the situation. It can involve [[heavy equipment]] like cranes, [[grader]]s, [[bulldozer]]s, or [[excavator]]s, and also hand processes like the planting of trees and other vegetation. It can involve high-tech processes such as those applied in the careful environmental control required in fish-hatchery procedures. Today, computerized regulation is often being utilized in these processes. Computer-based mapping has also become an important dimension of restorative work, as has [[computer modeling]].
In some situations, environmental restorative work is handled entirely by professionals working with skilled operators and technicians. In others, ordinary local community members may do much of the work, acquiring skills as the project proceeds. An example of this approach can be seen in Project Maitai<ref>[https://arcg.is/1XCCrj Project Maitai]</ref> where the Nelson City Council, New Zealand, has worked with community groups, such as Friends of the Maitai and local schools, to restore the [[Maitai River]] and its tributaries.
==Ecological restoration markets== Although the international field of restoration is driven primarily by the non-profit, government and academic sectors, in the U.S and certain other countries (e.g. Australia, which has a robust mining restoration sector), there are active markets for ecological restoration. The U.S. market blossomed shortly after U.S. created a law that prevents the loss of streams and wetlands under the [[Clean Water Act]] and in the wake of the passage of the [[Endangered Species Act]]. The Under Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 also created restoration opportunities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zipper|first1=CE|last2=Burger|first2=JA|last3=Skousen|first3=JG|last4=Angel|first4=PN|title=Restoring forests and associated ecosystem services on appalachian coal surface mines|journal=Environmental management|volume=47|issue=5|pages=751–756|doi=10.1007/s00267-011-9670-z}}</ref> When regulations stemming from these laws came online in the mid-1980s, there were few firms that were qualified or experienced in performing large-scale restoration projects. The first estimate of the dollars and jobs in the U.S. was $9.5 billion in annual sales, with 126,000 people employed.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=BenDor|first1=JM|last2=Newton|first2=AC|last3=Diaz|first3=A|last4=Bullock|first4=JM|title=Estimating the Size and Impact of the Ecological Restoration Economy|journal=PLoS ONE|date=2015|volume=10|issue=6|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0128339}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Biodegradation]] *[[Bioremediation]] *[[Buffalo Commons]] *[[Dutch standards]] *[[Industrial nature]] *[[List of environment topics]] *[[Natural attenuation]] *[[Phytoremediation]] *[[Richard St. Barbe Baker]] *[[Stream restoration]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category multi|Environmental restoration|Restoration of habitats}} *[http://www.ser.org/ Society for Ecological Restoration] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050207065518/http://www.arches.uga.edu/~esudduth/generallinks.html Stream Restoration Links] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050325133059/http://dizzy.library.arizona.edu/library/teams/set/wildlife/wfsc696clibres.html Restoration Ecology Links] *[http://www.restore-earth.org/ Restore the Earth site] *[http://www.desertrestore.org/ Arid Lands and Desert Restoration] * [http://www.youcanchangetheplanet.org Sustainable Ecological Restoration] . * [http://aspwe.rcharney.com/ American Society of Professional Wetland Engineers (ASPWE)] *[http://www.eemp.org EEMP] - a non-profit 501 (c) 3 organization dedicated to communicate the lessons of rehabilitation through media around the world.
